metadata.title: Secure Supply Chain Consumption Framework (S2C2F) Requirements
metadata.remarks: The following controls represent the S2C2F v1.1 (https://github.com/ossf/s2c2f/blob/main/specification/framework.md) for the purposes of assessing secure development pracices in alignment with S2C2F requirements for a given software project or product*. Copyrights for this work are held by the Linux Foundation Open Source Security Foundation (OpenSSF).

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can ship any existing asset if external OSS sources are compromised or unavailable.

controls.title: Use public package managers trusted by your organization (i.e. NuGet.org, npmjs.com, PyPi.org, etc.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Your organization benefits from the inherent security provided by the chosen trusted public package manager. Consuming open source from other sources should be deeped risky.

controls.title: Use an OSS binary repository manager solution (i.e. JFrog Artifactory, Azure Artifacts, etc.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Caches a local copy of the OSS artifact and protects against left-pad incidents, enabling developers to continue to build even if upstream resources are unavailable.

controls.title: Have a Deny List capability to block known malicious OSS from being consumed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Prevents ingestion of known malware by blocking ingestion as soon as a critically vulnerable OSS component is identified, such as colors v 1.4.1, or if an OSS component is deemed malicious.

controls.title: Mirror a copy of all OSS source code to an internal location

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery (BCDR) scenarios. Also enables proactive security scanning, fix it scenarios, and ability to rebuild OSS in a trusted build environment.

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I know if any OSS artifact in my pipeline has vulnerabilities or malware.

controls.title: Scan OSS for known vulnerabilities (i.e. CVEs, GitHub Advisories, etc.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Able to update OSS to reduce risks.

controls.title: Scan OSS for licenses

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Ensure your organization remains in compliance with the software license.

controls.title: Scan OSS to determine if its end-of-life

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For security purposes, no organization should take a dependency on software that is no longer receiving updates.

controls.title: Scan OSS for malware

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Able to prevent ingestion of malware into your CI/CD environment.

controls.title: Perform proactive security review of OSS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identify zero-day vulnerabilities and confidentially contribute fixes back to the upstream maintainer.

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I know where OSS artifacts are deployed in production.

controls.title: Maintain an automated inventory of all OSS used in development

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Able to respond to incidents by knowing who is using what OSS where. This can also be accomplished by generating SBOMs for your software.

controls.title: Have an OSS Incident Response Plan

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This is a defined, repeatable process that enables your organization to quickly respond to reported OSS incidents.

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can deploy updated external artifacts soon after an update becomes publicly available.

controls.title: Update vulnerable OSS manually

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Ability to resolve vulnerabilities.

controls.title: Enable automated OSS updates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Improve MTTR to patch faster than adversaries can operate.

controls.title: Display OSS vulnerabilities as comments in Pull Requests (PRs).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PR reviewer doesn't want to approve knowing that there are unaddressed vulnerabilities.

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can prove that every OSS artifact in production has a full chain-of-custody from the original artifact source and is consumed through the official supply chain.

controls.title: Verify the provenance of your OSS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Able to track that a given OSS package traces back to a repo

controls.title: Audit that developers are consuming OSS through the approved ingestion method

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Detect when developers consume OSS that isn't detected by your inventory or scan tools.

controls.title: Validate integrity of the OSS that you consume into your build

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Validate digital signature or hash match for each component

controls.title: Validate SBOMs of OSS that you consume into your build

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Validate SBOM for provenance data, dependencies, and its digital signature for SBOM integrity

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can rely on secure and trusted OSS consumption within my organization.

controls.title: Securely configure your package source files (i.e. nuget.config, .npmrc, pip.conf, pom.xml, etc.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By using NuGet package source mapping, or a single upstream feed, or using version pinning and lock files, you can protect yourself from race conditions and Dependency Confusion attacks

controls.title: Enforce usage of a curated OSS feed that enhances the trust of your OSS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Curated OSS feeds can be systems that scan OSS for malware, validate claims-metadata about the component, or systems that enforce an allow/deny list. Developers should not be allowed to consume OSS outside of the curated OSS feed.

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can rebuild from source code every OSS artifact I'm deploying.

controls.title: Rebuild the OSS in a trusted build environment, or validate that it is reproducibly built.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mitigates against build-time attacks such as those seen on CCleaner and SolarWinds. Open Source developers could introduce scripts or code that aren't present in the repository into the build process or be building in a compromised environment.

controls.title: Digitally sign the OSS you rebuild

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protect the integrity of the OSS you use.

controls.title: Generate SBOMs for OSS that you rebuild

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Captures the supply chain information for each package to enable you to better maintain your dependencies, auditability, and blast radius assessments

controls.title: Digitally sign the SBOMs you produce

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Ensures that consumers of your SBOMs can trust that the contents have not been tampered with

parts.name: objective
parts.prose: I can privately patch, build, and deploy any external artifact within 3 days of harm notification and confidentially contribute the fix to the upstream maintainer.

controls.title: Implement a change in the code to address a zero-day vulnerability, rebuild, deploy to your organization, and confidentially contribute the fix to the upstream maintainer

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To be used only in extreme circumstances when the risk is too great and to be used temporarily until the upstream maintainer issues a fix.
